description: Enterprise techniques used by OilRig, ATT&CK group G0049 v1.3
name: OilRig (G0049)

techniques.comment: OilRig has run net user, net user /domain, net group "domain admins" /domain, and net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain to get account listings on a victim.[3]
OilRig has run net user, net user /domain, net group "domain admins" /domain, and net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain to get account listings on a victim.[3]
OilRig has used HTTP for C2.[5][10][13]
OilRig has used DNS for C2.[5][10][13]
OilRig has used automated collection.[5]
OilRig has used brute force techniques to obtain credentials.[10]
OilRig has used various types of scripting for execution.[6][11][9][7][12]
OilRig has used PowerShell scripts for execution, including use of a macro to run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.[6][8][14]
OilRig has used macros to deliver malware such as QUADAGENT and OopsIE.[6][11][9][7][12] OilRig has used batch scripts.[6][11][9][7][12]
OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[5][10][15][13]

OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[5][10][15][13] OilRig has also used tools named VALUEVAULT and PICKPOCKET to dump passwords from web browsers.[13]
A OilRig macro has run a PowerShell command to decode file contents. OilRig has also used certutil to decode base64-encoded files on victims.[6][8][9]
OilRig used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[10]
OilRig has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.[4]
OilRig uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.[10]
OilRig malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.[11]
OilRig has deleted files associated with their payload after execution.[6][9]
OilRig can download remote files onto victims.[6]
OilRig has used keylogging tools called KEYPUNCH and LONGWATCH.[10][13]
OilRig has used the publicly available tool SoftPerfect Network Scanner as well as a custom tool called GOLDIRONY to conduct network scanning.[10]
OilRig has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.[6][7][5][14][12]
OilRig has tested malware samples to determine AV detection and subsequently modified the samples to ensure AV evasion.[1][12]
OilRig has abused the Outlook Home Page feature for persistence. OilRig has also used CVE-2017-11774 to roll back the initial patch designed to protect against Home Page abuse.[17]
OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as Mimikatz to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[5][10][15][13]
OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[5][10][15][13]
OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[5][10][15][13]
OilRig has used net.exe in a script with net accounts /domain to find the password policy of a domain.[16]
OilRig has used net localgroup administrators to find local administrators on compromised systems.[3]
OilRig has used net group /domain, net group "domain admins" /domain, and net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain to find domain group permission settings.[3]
OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.[9][7][14]
OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious links to potential victims.[9]
OilRig has used LinkedIn to send spearphishing links.[13]
OilRig has run tasklist on a victim's machine.[3]
OilRig has used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[5][10][13]
OilRig has used reg query "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default" on a victim to query the Registry.[3]
OilRig has used Putty to access compromised systems.[5]
OilRig has used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement. The group has also used tunneling tools to tunnel RDP into the environment.[5][10]
OilRig has created scheduled tasks that run a VBScript to execute a payload on victim machines.[9][7][13]
OilRig has a tool called CANDYKING to capture a screenshot of user's desktop.[10]
OilRig has used Web shells, often to maintain access to a victim network.[5][10]
OilRig has used a CHM payload to load and execute another malicious file once delivered to a victim.[3]
OilRig has run hostname and systeminfo on a victim.[3][4][13]
OilRig has run ipconfig /all on a victim.[3][4]
OilRig has used netstat -an on a victim to get a listing of network connections.[3]
OilRig has run whoami on a victim.[3][4]
OilRig has used sc query on a victim to gather information about services.[3]
OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[5][10][15][13]
OilRig has delivered macro-enabled documents that required targets to click the "enable content" button to execute the payload on the system.[9][7][14]
OilRig has delivered malicious links to achieve execution on the target system.[9][7][14]
OilRig has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.[5][10]
OilRig has used WMI for execution.[10]
